Package org.dyn4j.geometry.decompose

This package contains algorithms to decompose polygons into Convex pieces.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    Decomposer
    Represents an algorithm to decompose a given list of points representing a polygon into a list of convex pieces.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    Bayazit
    Implementation of the Bayazit convex decomposition algorithm.
    DoublyConnectedEdgeList
    Highly specialized DCEL class used to store vertices of a simple polygon and then be used to create and store triangulations and convex decompositions.
    EarClipping
    Implementation of the Ear Clipping algorithm.
    MonotoneChain
    Represents a monotone chain.
    MonotonePolygon<E>
    Represents a monotone polygon.
    MonotoneVertex<E>
    Represents a vertex of a monotone polygon.
    SweepLine
    Performs the Sweep Line algorithm to decompose the given polygon into y-monotone pieces which are then used to triangulate the original polygon.
    SweepLine.Edge
    Represents an edge of a polygon storing the next and previous edges and the vertices that make up this edge.
    SweepLine.EdgeBinaryTree
    Class to extend the BinarySearchTree to add a method for finding the SweepLine.Edge closest to a given SweepLine.Vertex.
    SweepLine.Vertex
    Represents a vertex on a polygon that stores information about the left and right edges and left and right vertices.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    MonotoneChain.Type
    Enumeration of monotone chain types.
    MonotonePolygon.Type
    Enumeration of the types of monotone polygons supported.
    SweepLine.Vertex.Type
    Enumeration of the SweepLine.Vertex types.

Package org.dyn4j.geometry.decompose Description

This package contains algorithms to decompose polygons into Convex pieces.

Three implementations of the Decomposer interface are provided: Bayazit, EarClipping, and SweepLine.

The Bayazit algorithm is O(nr) and finds a non-optimal convex decomposition.

The EarClipping algorithm is O(n2) and finds a valid triangulation, then uses the Hertel-Mehlhorn algorithm to combine triangles into convex pieces. This is also an non-optimal decomposition.

The SweepLine algorithm is O(n log n) and, like EarClipping, finds a valid triangulation, then uses the Hertel-Mehlhorn algorithm to combine triangles into convex pieces. This is also a non-optimal decomposition.

In general the algorithms will generate different decompositions. If used for pre-processing just choose the best result, for runtime generation, the Bayazit may be slower but will generally produce a better decomposition.

A "better" decomposition is one that contains fewer convex pieces and the convex pieces that are created are of better quality for simulation.

Since:
2.2.0
Version:
2.2.2
Author:
William Bittle
